abstract: Sound arguments about regulating too-big-to-fail financial institutions may lose out to a barrage of advertisements and campaign spending on behalf of Republicans, an economist writes.
snippet: Sound arguments about regulating too-big-to-fail financial institutions may lose out to a barrage of advertisements and campaign spending on behalf of Republicans, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline.main: Will There Be a Meaningful Volcker Rule?

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)

abstract: A group of Bear Stearns shareholders who claimed to have been hurt by the investment bank’s deteriorating health has agreed to settle its claims for $275 million, four years after the firm was sold to JPMorgan Chase.
snippet: A group of Bear Stearns shareholders who claimed to have been hurt by the investment bank’s deteriorating health has agreed to settle its claims for $275 million, four years after the firm was sold to JPMorgan Chase.
lead_paragraph: A group of Bear Stearns shareholders who claimed to have been hurt by the investment bank’s deteriorating health agreed on Wednesday to settle its claims for $275 million, four years after the firm was sold to JPMorgan Chase.

headline.main: Bear Stearns Investors Settle Claims for $275 Million

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced
